messageBody:
Kent,

Thank you so much for answering this question!

> If you can't share fixture code by inheritance, then perhaps you can
share
> it by delegation. Could you have several Fixture classes, one
hierarchy per
> interface hierarchy, and construct the appropriate fixtures in setUp()?

What I'm already doing is creating a TestCases (or a hierarchy where
appropriate) for each interface. These test cases are used directly as
base classes when I'm testing a class implementing only one interface.

My problem is using delegation when I have to combine several of these
test cases. I understand what delegation is, and I know how to use it
with simple objects. But then again, JUnit fixtures still seem really
mysterious to me :-).

I can probably start with getting my head around Mikhail Shnayderman's
answer (http://groups.yahoo.com/group/junit/message/14534) and yours
of course.

I'm going to "do my homework" now and try to come up with something as
easy to use/understand as I can. I'll come back for advice on my solution.

In the meantime, I have found a workaround thanks to Joe Rainsberger's
answer (http://groups.yahoo.com/group/junit/message/14535) and Jason
Tibbetts' (http://groups.yahoo.com/group/junit/message/14549) bonus tip.

I posted an answer to the latter containing a working code sample
(http://groups.yahoo.com/group/junit/message/14558). However, after
trying it "on the field", I chose to stick with Joe's simpler solution
in order not to end up with possibly large test classes containing
several "interface-specific" internal classes.

Modern IDE's make it easy to navigate in such files, but I tend to
like my files short and to avoid internal classes.

To be honest I had never thought about studying the internals of JUnit
before I faced this problem. You guys made it so easy to write tests
without knowing anything about how JUnit was implemented that I
thought I would never have to :-) (damn I'm lazy!).

Thanks again for taking the time to answer my question and thank you
and Erich Gamma for JUnit and your contributions to evolution of
software development!

Dimitri
